name: Plants vs. Zombies GOTY Edition
description: Zombies are invading your home, and the only defense is your arsenal of plants! Armed with an alien nursery-worth of zombie-zapping plants like peashooters and cherry bombs, you'll need to think fast and plant faster to stop dozens of types of zombies dead in their tracks.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP/Vista/7                     Processor: 1.2GHz+ processor                     Memory: 1GB of RAM                     Graphics: 128MB of video memory, 16-bit or 32-bit color quality                     DirectX: DirectX 8 or later                     Hard Drive: 65+MB of free hard drive space                     Sound: DirectX-compatible sound

I didn't intend to cover this game originally, but then I figured it was certainly a big enough name to justify, and also a good enough game to talk about. Before Plants VS Zombies was following in the footsteps of Team Fortress 2 and interrupting an indie developer with mood-destroying music at every E3, it started here, as a simple tower defense. This is a kind that's a bit less common on Steam, where you're defending rows rather than winding path. As the title implies, you do this using militaristic plants to combat a bunch of eccentric zombies.  Compared to a lot of the games I've talked about, Plants VS Zombies is a pretty casual one. Experience in many of the above titles would make the campaign fairly easy to get through, and even when I played it years ago without any TD experience I don't remember having much trouble. Of course, not every game needs to be hard, far from it, and there's something relaxing about watching your garden take on all comers. Both your plants and the zombies are also both appealing enough to look at without trying too hard, and there's a good amount of enemy variety.  You start with a simple Peashooter for damage and a Sunflower for harvesting resources (you do need to manually click on them like Beware Earth, but that's the only thing like it in the game and it's not generally very hectic), and across the course of the campaign get access to forty-seven others that all have some different use, depending on what zombies you're up against or the level. The game mixes things up often enough to keep things from getting too repetitive, and aside from the normal sunny day you'll also have to defend at night, where you get less resources, or at the backyard pool, where you have to build terrain for most of your plants to stand on. You'll also get levels within those that operate on different rules, such as using the Wallnut to bowl down zombies or having to pick your defenses from a sort of conveyor belt.  Aside from the campaign there are a bunch of minigames and alternate modes you can unlock, including survival and a role reversal where you pick zombies to go after the plants' defenses. Quite a lot considering the game's only five dollars, the cheapest of any game mentioned so far. If you're looking for a more low-key entry into tower defenses, it would be a good one to pick up, as long as you remember most other ones aren't exactly like this. Even if you're not new to them though, if you somehow haven't played this I can't think of any reason to dissuade you.

Oh man, Plants vs. Zombies GOTYE, it blew my dang mind! When I saw a photo of it, I was like, 'That game looks odd.' Well, nowadays, I think this game is just so cool. The plants you can plant (especialy the gatling pea and cattail), the variety of zombies, heck, even the ACHIVEMENTS are cool. One of the thing I also have to like about this is the frickin' final boss music. It is so freaking awesome! Anyway, other than the adventure mode, there also is stuff like puzzles and even endless survival to keep you playing. One of the things I think the developer did so well on was the Zen Garden mode. The music is calm, and it can be fun growing the plants and collecting the money they give. Pretty much, for anyone who wants a good tower defense game, they should get Plants vs Zombies GOTYE. This game deserves a 10-10, and/or a 4.9-5 star rating, only because of the fact that the second time playing adventure mode, Crazy Dave will pick three plants that possibly would be useless. Still, this game is awesome. Enough said.

You play as some sort of magical wizard gardener or something who uses sentient plants to defend your wizard brains against hordes of the undead who shuffle single-file through your front yard.   The plants and zombies take on many forms, from your standard ambling corpse to pole-vaulting zombies to zombies riding on zombie dolphins in your pool. The plants do everything from produce sunlight (the source of your magic powers) to shoot flaming peas at your decomposing foes.  It's a fun point and clicky game with a very nice difficulty curve. New plants and zombies are introduced on a regular basis to keep things fresh but never in an overwhelming fashion.  It's definitely the best plant-based zombie-defense wizard game I've ever played.

Simple, cheap and addictive fun!  Some comedic value too! It also has a progressive challenge that towards the mid to later levels, the game gets quite challenging. A definite recommended title from Neon Anderson! (lol)

Whether you're a new fan to the zombie craze, a veteran undead-lover, or love gardening in general, you won't be disappointed with this great time-killer of a game. And once you do, you'll see why this is one of the indie greats!

I've loved Plants vs. Zombies for years now and although the game gets repetitive, it never fails to come up with new ways to change things up and entertain me! Completing PvZ is possible only a third of what the game has to offer. Once you've played the whole story mode through once, there is so much more you can do, for example; Minigames, Endless Survival, Upgrading, Tree Of Wisdom just to name a few and of course a garden would not be complete without the defined range of Crazy Dave's Twiddydinkies either.   After completing the story mode once, there is still opportunity to go back to complete those achievements you couldn't quite get or missed the first time round by playing it again. The replay value of this game is great as it offers new rewards for completing levels and waves to the play and as you can see, I've spent hours playing myself getting hooked to the occasional game every now and then.  Personally, I highly recommend this game if you're into fast paced strategy games although that is what this game is mostly limited to. With the cool editional features to the Game Of The Year Edition for example the Zombie Creator and new achievements to get stuck into, it really is worth some extra cash if you feel you would enjoy the game enough to play through at least once. Sadly it does lack some cool features that come with the Xbox 360 edition but overall, a solid game! 8/10

I may be late to the game for this review, but I've been a fan of 'Plants vs. Zombies' for years (having played it on my cellphone and tablet). I picked it up on Steam because, honestly, $4.99 for a GOTY edition is well worth it. The game is a tower defense game, in which you use plants to defend your home from zombies (hence the title of the game). As you play, you unlock new plants to use, as well as mini-games (which I highly recommend the bowling mini-game as soon as you unlock it to rack up some easy money). Speaking of money, you use it to buy various upgrades, such as more seed slots (you pick what plants you use before you start each stage), or upgraded plants themselves. The mix of defensive and offensive plants you get is great, and overall, the game is just fun to play. If you haven't gotten it on PC yet, or simply have yet to try it (which there is a demo on Steam available to try before you buy), I highly recommend picking it up.

A game you can pick up and play in minutes, useful for the odd few moments when you're unsure of what to play or have 5 mins and don't want to get stuck into something bigger. Plants Vs Zombies is a gun twist on a tower defense game and features you literally growing plants on your lawn, swimming pool and rooftop to stop the zombies from eating your brains.  The game is quite replayable, the first run through has several stages and keeps the gameplay interesting by adding hazards such as fog, mini-games like bowling & slots and even some puzzle modes to keep all audiences interested. 2x play throughs of the adventure mode are required to see everything and you can replay the mini games & puzzles at will once they're unlocked.  For the score setters, the game features survival modes & even an endless mode just to see how many waves you can last.  There's also a 'Zen Garden' where you grow plants without figting zombies and can have several gardens and a tree of wisdom, providing tips and codes to modify the games visuals.  The game looks a little dated due to the developers sticking with a 4:3 resolution and maximised on a 1920 x 1080 screen this can look a little pixelated - that doesn't impact the gameplay and even adds some charm to the game itself.  If you're looking for a casual game that will keep you interested over a long period of time and isn't overly difficult in the process, pick this up.

First review.  Plants vs. Zombies is a fun and addictive game aimed more towards the casual gamer. The graphics are quite cutsie and cartoony which I found enjoyable. The gameplay consists of clicking here and there to gather resources in way of sun to earn enough to plant more well... plants to fend off a zombie onslaught. There are many different types of plants to choose from to counter specific types of zombies. While at first I thought the game would get very repetitive, I soon learned that the different types of boards, plants and zombies kept each level feeling fairly fresh.  In conclusion, this was a simple game that provided hours of cheap entertainment. 8.5/10

The importance of garden design has never been quite as life or death as this!  Dr Edgar George Zomboss is sending his hordes of loyal zombie followers at your house, with only one thing on their mind - yours! Your only line of defense is to put your planting skills to use and allow your flower friends to take out the undead trash! They attack day and night, and from all approaches (including on the roof and down the chimney!), so be prepared to mix and match your plants to make sure you don't lose your head!  A simple but effective tower defense game with a lot of thought and humour put into it. (Shame that PopCap got bought out by the overlord$ at EA...) Certainly a good addition to anyone's games library.

**14 Hours as of this review**   Years ago, I used to play a Nintendo DS Lite. Plants vs. Zombies was the best game I have ever played. Years passed, and I moved on to Nintendo 3DS, Xbox 360, and now PC (plan to stay here, lol.) Here I am today, and I picked up Plants vs. Zombies Game of the Year Edition for $2.49 in a Steam sale. Many memories were retained and experienced again. Disregarding those memories, this game proved itself to be a very great game, not the best I have played anymore, due to my wide array of game knowledge, but it does hold a title of awesomeness. BUY THIS EXTRA SEED SLOT FOR $20,000,000  I'M  CRAAAAAZY   This is, yes, a 'casual' tower defense game. It's also quite fun, with charming graphics and humor, and actually somewhat challenging in the later stages. You'll certainly have a lot of options and playstyles to choose from by then, at least.  In PvZ, the dead have risen and they're coming for your brains. Luckily, you seem to have stolen several decades' worth of experimental plant seeds from the US government, which you must now use to defend your home from the undead menace. This is not actually the plot, but it's my headcanon.  You must collect sun that drops from the sky (when it's daytime, that is) and from sun-generating plants. Sun is used to place your plants in various areas around your rather upscale home. The plants range from Peashooters to LSoH-esque Chompers to Potato Mines; you have a lot of ways to destroy the zeds. And you're going to need them, because these are apparently Romero-type zombies that know how to do stuff like bounce on pogo sticks, ride dolphins and whatever they can do to crush your organic defenses. (They sport Left 4 Dead-like mutations as well, but I'm getting ahead of myself.)  The game is easy to pick up, but it'll throw some curveballs your way from time to time. Various additional modes and features are unlocked as you progress through the campaign for the first time, which is neat.  I suppose a description of this game in a nutshell would be 'simple and fun, but not  too  simple, and pretty well-designed to boot'. It's probably a minor classic by this point. At the very least, it doesn't have microtransactions like its sequel.

(Will change recommendation if problem is fixed.)  So, for starters, I'll begin with the fact that this game is ... frankly awesome. The atmosphere is very enjoyable. +The Music is catchy +The levels start you off easy to get you used to the simple mechanics. Progressively getting more and more difficult. +In the same context of the previous positive, the levels also change as the game progresses. (Less aisles to place defenses. Day / Night. Fog. Square blockers [Places you can't put defense plants] Front yard, back yard, roof, pool etc. +Plethora of various plants you can choose from, level to level. [Same context, plenty of various zombies as well. That also get more challenging in their abilities or 'tricks' you have to deal with] +Handful of mini-games to change the pace, when you're tired of this games equivelent of a story mode.  Honestly, aside from the main reason I'm not recommending this game, I can think of very few negative aspects of game. Which is namely the fact that I can't actually play the game for extended periods of time. Which I believe is more a personal aspect, as opposed to anything wrong with the game. As matches get harder, I find myself playing one or two levels and then giving it a break, and playing a different game.  However, the extremely sad, and utterly heart breaking fact is that all of the above positives don't matter in the slightest, because you can't play the game. At all. Period. A recent update and it simply broke. You see the logo for Pop Games, and then you get a black screen. Nothing can be done except alt-tabbing out and closing, or alt-cntrl-dlt and closing the program that way. Such a huge let down. And it still hasn't been fixed, almost a month out (at the time of this review.) Yes ... I waited almost a full month, giving them the benefit of the doubt that they were fixing this. As stated, this review might very well change, and quickly, assuming they fix this problem. What a huge waste of time, energy, and money as of this moment.

While Plants vs. Zombies is a really fun time-waster, I can't say I thoroughly enjoyed it to the end. The achievements rapidly become grindy, and gameplay is almost exactly the same from level to level. Though the developers attempt to offset this by introducing new mechanics, the forced second playthrough of the campaign and seemingly pointless records you must reach to complete the game really put a damper on the fun I got out of it. If it's exceedingly cheap (as it usually is), I might suggest you pick it up just for a casual break in between real games, but overall, I wouldn't buy this unless it's dirt cheap.  If that was all I had to say, I might consider recommending this game. However, the Mac version of it is exceedingly poor. I typically play on my PC, but when I tried it out on my girlfriend's MacBook Pro, the amount of glitches and crashes were simply astronomical. The game would crash roughly every ten or fifteen minutes, and gameplay would sometimes lag to hell and back. I did, however, sell a plant in my Zen Garden for $1,240,996 (they typically go for about $60-$300), so I got that goin' for me, which is nice. A glitch that works CRAZY much in my favor, however, is still a glitch. I would stay away from this if you plan to use it on a Mac.
